Ran tests on HDInsight. It seems that there may be a possible race condition in our closing of completed Evaluators, which caused the restart scenario to fail once and I haven't seen it since. A separate JIRA is filed here:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-726. Thanks!

I did a pass. My main concern lies with the usage of memory streams. I am not sure how safe it is to reuse instances of them. Also, performance shouldn't be our prime concern here. Hence, I suggest not to reuse them.

Also, wouldn't it be better to wrap access to them in `using()` statements? That way, we get some guaranteed cleanup even if things crash.
I've done some syntax level checks, will have a look with an IDE later.

I see. I will modify it.

Dhruv

[REEF-pull-request-windows3 #403](https://builds.apache.org/job/REEF-pull-request-windows3/403/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

I'm having trouble following the logic in the failed evaluator case. To my understanding, there is control flow fork based on whether or not we are in the IMRU phase or still in the load phase. If we are in IMRU, Evaluator failure shall indicate job failure, correct?

Now, in the data load phase, the logic seems a bit more complex than it needs to be to me. Let me try to describe the logic as it makes sense to me below:

We need the following data structures:
- A set of tasks to submit `TasksToSubmit`,
- a set of submitted tasks `TasksSubmitted`,
- a set of running tasks `TasksRunning` and
- a dictionary from evaluator ID to successfully completed task `TasksCompleted`.

The value type of these would capture the configuration of the Task as well as any other metadata we might need. Given those data structures, the event handlers do the following:
- `OnNext(IDriverStarted)` fills `TasksToSubmit` and requests enough Evaluators.
- `OnNext(IAllocatedEvaluator)` submits the context and service configurations we need.
- `OnNext(IActiveContext)` moves the task from `TasksToSubmit` to `TasksSubmitted`.  If we are past the load phase, it submits an IMRU task.
- `OnNext(IRunningTask)` moves it from `TasksSubmitted` to `TasksRunning`
- `OnNext(ICompletedTask)` moves it from `TasksRunning` to `TasksCompleted`. This handler also decides whether or not we have completed the load phase.
- `OnNext(IFailedEvaluator)` looks up the task in `TasksRunning` and moves it back to `TasksToSubmit`. It also requests another Evaluator.

Of course, all of these have an `if` to decide whether or not we are still in the load phase. It could make sense to capture all of this in an object which is an `IObservable<IActiveContext>` for the contexts on which the load tasks completed successfully. Although we might want to wrap the `IActiveContext` in additional metadata about the partition and such.

Does this make sense?
@beysims Thanks! I will merge.
I'll do a pass.

Also, I wonder whether we could attack [REEF-383](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-383) as part of this or whether we should do that separately. Once this change is in, the likely solution to REEF-383 seems to be to delete `JavaBridge` altogether.
@afchung I've addressed your feedback and rebased onto current `master`. Time for another look.

Lemme get back to this tonight or after going back. Want to finish
somethings before that.

Dhruv

[REEF-pull-request-windows3 #406](https://builds.apache.org/job/REEF-pull-request-windows3/406/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

This assumes that the release message from YARN is the last message, correct? What if we get the YARN message first and then the final heartbeat? I believe that is what `EvaluatorManager.isResourceReleased` was introduced for.
@markusweimer No, this works in either case because both end up calling `close()`, and whoever wins the race will be the one to release the Evaluator.

In other words, if we get the final heartbeat later, we will just ignore the message because `this.stateManager.isDoneOrFailedOrKilled()` would have been set to true. `onResourceStatusMessage()` and `onEvaluatorHeartbeatMessage()` are both synchronized on `this.evaluatorDescriptor`.
